Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding Professors Ivan Dmochowski and Jeffrey Saven at the University of Pennsylvania to study nanoparticles and their interactions with proteins. Nanoparticles are used in a wide variety of applications, from biomedical diagnostics to consumer electronics. The colors and electronic properties of these systems depend on their sizes and compositions. The isolation of particles having targeted sizes and properties, as well as making such particles more "bio-friendly", remain bottlenecks to further study and application. This project targets the design and creation of stable, mutually compatible protein-nanoparticle systems through control of protein-protein interactions at the nanoparticle surface. These studies seek to provide general design principles for controlling interactions at protein-inorganic nanomaterial interfaces, principles that could have broad applicability in nanotechnology, materials science and biomedicine. Graduate students, undergraduates, and summer research students will be trained in a multi-disciplinary environment combining experimental and computational approaches. Lectures and laboratory exercises will be developed to engage high school participants in a summer program that features current research involving bio-nanotechnology, bioinorganic and computational chemistry.

Ferritin proteins will be designed to form stable, reversible, and native-like assemblies with inorganic nanoparticles. A long-term goal is to selectively encapsulate and separate nanoparticles, for example, fluorescent CdSe (cadmium selenide) quantum dots or Au, Ag, and Pt nanoparticles,based on their size, surface ligands, or composition. In Aim 1, variants of stable ferritin oligomers will be computationally designed to understand the assembly process and to accelerate formation of the 24mer holoprotein. In Aim 2, the interaction of these designed proteins with inorganic nanoparticles will be investigated to characterize stability and propensities for rapid and selective nanoparticle encapsulation. The design of these ferritins aims to expand the range of inorganic materials that can be stably and selectively encapsulated.

Institution.Name: University of Pennsylvania
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: The Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview.  This 3-year NSF-sponsored project produced 8 peer-reviewed publications, 2 review articles, and 1 book chapter in communicating several recent discoveries that thermophilic ferritin from A. fulgidus (AfFtn) can form stable, stoichiometric, reversible, and native-like 24mer assemblies that encapsulate approximately two supercharged (+36) green fluorescent proteins (GFPs), or one 6-nm BSPP-coated gold nanoparticle (AuNP). Guided by computational design, several ferritin variants were developed. AfFtn is an uniquely well-defined model system for studying bio-nano supramolecular self-assembly and bio-nano interfaces.

Intellectual Merit.  Host-guest chemistry has been widely explored with small molecules and served to identify weak interactions that contribute to high affinity and specificity. Much less is known about larger, endohedral protein-protein or protein-nanoparticle host-guest interactions. The process of protein encapsulation has biological significance in chaperone-assisted protein folding, but de novo systems for systematic investigation of single protein encapsulation have been lacking. NPs have broad application in medicine, catalysis, and energy generation.  Many properties that emerge at the nanoscale are sensitive to the size, shape and composition of the particles, but isolation of particles with targeted sizes and properties, as well as ?bio-compatibility?, remain bottlenecks to further application. Proteins hold considerable promise for programming the design of complex structures and functions on nanometer-to-millimeter scales. This project has created stable, mutually compatible protein-NP systems through careful control of protein-protein interactions at the nanoparticle surface. The Aims of this project fully integrated the expertise of the co-PIs in computational design and experimental studies of proteins and NPs.

Broader Impacts.  Medical school collaborators have determined that suitably modified AfFtn can deliver therapeutic enzyme cargo into the mouse vascular endothelium, by targeting caveolae. This versatile approach takes advantage of ferritin?s size (~12 nm), monodispersity, controllable assembly/disassembly, and ease of external functionalization with antibody targeting moieties. All aspects of the ferritin project have provided multidisciplinary training opportunities for more than 30 UPenn graduate students, undergraduates, NSF-REU and Univ. Puerto Rico students and faculty. Many of these undergraduate students have gone on to pursue Ph.D. degrees in Chemistry-related disciplines, and many Ph.D. graduates have won gainful employment in the chemical industry and academia. The results of these studies have been widely disseminated via public databases, internet sites, journal articles, public lectures, and outreach programs. The current cover of Protein Science (Oct 2018) showcases this work, highlighting a ferritin-GFP complex (see attached figure). The co-PIs have developed laboratory and classroom activities that are being used by middle school and high school students in Philadelphia.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2018
Modified by: Ivan J Dmochowski

  • Ferritin was engineered to encapsulate two supercharged GFP molecules

    Thermophilic Ferritin Encapsulating Two GFP Molecules
